ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is a relatively time-consuming classes. You would need to read and study a lot on your own to really know those spectroscopies if you are not familiar with it before.There are 2 mid-terms and 1 final paper/presentation.

I would recommend it for those interested in either spectroscopy or those who have any interest in biochemistry. It was a good class that delves into spectroscopic methods that may be new and covers how they can be used to study metalloproteins.
I would recommend this course to anyone in inorganic or chem bio as it has relevant techniques and information for both topics.
A good class for students interested in the subject. Final paper and presentation prepares for the future task of a researcher.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Get a big picture of different spectroscopy skills. Some of them are widely-used in researches, especially in bio-inorganic.

This course gave me the background for understanding a wide variety of metalloenzymes, which are applicable to natural product discovery and study of the biosynthesis. It also provided the background needed to understand the literature in this field.
The subject is applicable to my research so the course was very helpful
